_items.title: We respond
_items.body: We respond to spiritual, pastoral and religious need. This supports the Trust's committment to provide holistic care.

_items.title: We affirm
_items.body: We affirm and nurture each person's search for meaning in and through the challenges of ill health.

_items.title: We help
_items.body: We help to sustain the faith practicse of those for whom religious observance is a vital and integral part of their lives.

_items.title: We work together
_items.body: We work together as people of differnet faiths and worldviews to provide these services to all.

The Royal College of Nursing offers a helpful definition:

“Spiritual Care recognises and responds to the needs of the human spirit when faced with trauma, ill health or sadness."

This can include the need for meaning, for self-worth, to express oneself, for faith support, perhaps for rites or prayer or sacrament, or simply for a sensitive listener.

Spiritual care begins with encouraging human contact in compassionate relationship, and moves in whatever direction the person’s need requires.”

For more information click here.

Spiritual Care is NOT

  • About your own beliefs and practices.
  • About imposing your own beliefs and values on another.

title: Component title
body:
In your role as a chaplaincy volunteer, you will meet people of many different backgrounds, faiths and beliefs.

Please think about:

  • How can you respond to so many different people?

The Chaplaincy Team includes people of many different backgrounds. But what do you have to offer?

One thing we can all do is listen and be attentive.

_items.body: Being in hospital can be very isolating, even on the busiest of wards. Sometimes patients are brought in from far off counties, and can be completely cut off from their usual support. Loneliness can be a very painful experience, and being a caring presence, we can help support patients during, what can be, a difficult time.

Patients may ask for specific religious support such as a prayer. If you are asked for something that you cannot do, for example administer Holy Communion, you are expected to refer on to the chaplain, who will arrange for it to be done.

Patients may be worried about the future. This may be about what is going to happen once they are discharged, or perhaps their own prognoses, or even end-of-life concerns. It can be very helpful for patients to talk about these things with another person, and to work through in their own minds, some of their concerns and anxieties. Again, if you feel out-of-your-depth, or uncertain, please check in with your mentor or other members of the chaplaincy team.

Being in hospital can be a very stressful time. Being away from your own home, sleeping in a strange bed, in a noisy ward, can be very distressing to some patients. Patients can become frustrated with medical staff if they do not get the answers or treatment they feel they need. Chaplains can provide a way of venting these anxieties and frustrations, and provide an outlet to stressed patients.

Patients frequently ask "why me", reflecting feelings of unfairness at what they are going through. Life often continues around them, but patients can feel as if their lives are over, or that they can't cope with being ill or being dependent on others. This can cause feelings of emptiness or upset, anger and frustration. Chaplains and volunteers can provide an avenue for patients to vent those frustrations.

Religious or theological questions, whilst not as common as you might expect, are something that patients may wish to engage in. You are not expected to be an expert, nor to answer questions about your own beliefs. Chaplaincy is there to provide a space for patients to work through their own understanding. However, you may share a person's faith, in which case you may be able to understand where the person is coming from, but do not assume this. Remember you can always refer on to a chplain if necessary.

title: Component title
body: In this video, chaplain Louie Savva describes some of the skills involved in active listening.

_items.title: When You Arrive
_items.body:
• Sign the "Chaplaincy Volunteers Record Sheet"
  • Check notice boards for any important news or information.
  • Check personal box or folder for messages.

_items.title: When You Reach The Ward
_items.body:
• Introduce yourself to staff as a Chaplaincy Volunteer.
  • Ask if there is anyone in particular who may appreciate a visit from chaplaincy.
  • Sign the ward volvunteer's folder, usually located near the nurses station.
  • Introduce yourself by name to patients and say you are a chaplaincy volunteer.
  • Be senstivie to the patient and let them set the agenda. Remember patients may not want to talk. Consider offering to pull the curtains around for extra privacy.

_items.title: Before You Leave
_items.body: Sign out before you leave!

Robert tells you about his succession of illnessnes, which have been getting more serious each time. He has been proud of providing for those he loves, but now says he is desperate. He says "You're a person of faith. Pray for me to get better. I need all the help I can get!".

Our role is to support people in the things that give them strenght and to encourage their independence.

Before praying we will probably wish to geive people the chance toe express the feelings and anxiestis that lie behind their request. Sensitive questions and listening may give them a greater sense of their own ability to deal with their illsnes. If they don't want to talk about it, we should respect that too.

Some epople may feel they have reached the end of their own resources. By praying with oneone we can help them to express their own desire for healing and wholeness. We should avaoid implying a promise of healing or imposing our own beliefs about healing.
Relax and stay calm.
Be aware of your own inner voice (what are you thinking and feeling?).
Avoid speaking too soon, too often, or too much.
Avoid loaded remarks or judgements.
Remember what the person has said, summarise or checke you've understood (this shows you've been listening).
Listen attentively to what the person is saying.
Listen to what else the person is saying (or what they're not saying).
Be sensitive to their mood and body language (is it communicating something different from their words?).
When we provide pastoral care, it's important to respect our patients boundaries and our own.
Respecting boundaries means we give people space and privacy; respect their individuality and self-determination; and don't impose ourselves or our own ideas, beliefs or feelings upon them.
By doing this we keep our patients safe and keep ourselves safe too.

_items.title: Maintain approproate relationships
_items.body: Maintain appropriate relationships (we aim for a proffesional relationship with patients - not like other relationships outside hospital such as friendships or belonging to the same group).

_items.title: Understand the inequality of power
_items.body: Understand the inequality of power between yourself and patients. Patients mayb be vulnerable. Or they might see you as an authority figure. At the simplest level, you can get up and walk away from your conversation but they can't!

_items.title: Be guided by patient's wishes or needs
_items.body: Be guided by patient's wishes or needs, obtain their consent for what you do, and try and enable them to take iniitatives for themselves (e.g., by resolving their own problems, or by communicating with staff for themselves).
Maintain confidentiality
Dont arrange to meet patients outside the hospital.
Avoid giving advice or offering help.
Don't judge people's lifestyle choices.
Allow people to be where they are, to ask questions and to express the fears they need to.
Meet the patient's needs, not your own.
Don't assume you know what the patient believes. If in doubt, ask them.

You visit a lady who has been admitted to hospital for the third time this year. Her last stay was for over 4 weeks. She seems very despondent and concerned about various family members who don't visit her. She lives alone. She says "I don't know what's going to become of me. I'm not getting any better. I feel ready to give up".

Our role is to listen and support.

We can't solve people's situations. Sometimes the best we can do is to make them feel slightly better or better able to cope. People often apprecaite someone who has the time to listen attentively while showing empathy.

We need to discern when people will benefit from cheering up or looking at their situation from a fresh perspective, or simplely being heard while they express negative feelings.

You meet a patient who seems very anxious and depressed. After you have been speaking for a while he says he believes he is going to be damned becuase he has rejected God in the past. He asks how he can prevent this happening to him.

Our role is to support people and not to impose our own beliefs.

If we offer a hasty response to a question about faith, we could close down a deeper conversation about the reasons for the other person's fears. Asking questions is often more helpful than giving answers.

You meet a patient who seems ill at ease. After talking for a while he says his partner is concerned about his health and wants to get married "for the sake of the children". They have one child, each from separate relationships , and a 2 year old child from their shared relationship. He says he doesn't want to be married again because of his previous relationship. He asks if you agree.

Our role is as facilitators, supporting people in reflecting on their own situation and coming to their own conclusiosn. We don't know all about their situation or what is really important to them.

If we give advice, we might prevent them reaching a good decision or gaining insight into their own feelings, ideas or values.

A very friendly patient is pleased to see you again. She asks how your family are and what you're going to de that weekend. You discover she comes from an area you know well and you have some aquaintances and interests in common.

Think how you might respond to her questions and what you might contribute to the conversation.

Our role is to listen and be attentive to the other person.

If we say too much about ourselves or other people, we might miss something important the patients wants to say about their own situation.

Brenda is a lady who seems very interested in religion. She attends a local place of worship and has taken its teaching very seriously. Religious practices seem to be an important part of who she is and her conversation shows that she has thought deeply about such things. Before you go she asks you to pray to bless a statue of her guardian angel as he will be looking after her during her illness.

Our spiritual care role in hospital is to support people in the things that give them strength.

Some faith traditions may include prayers to angels or blessing statues. Others may be uncomforatble with this. If we feel uncomfortable or that our integrity is breached, we could sensitively offer support from another team member or chaplain.

_items.title: Do
_items.body:
• Always sign in and out.
  • Use hand-gel between patients.
  • Introduce yorself to staff and patients.
  • Be sensitive to the patient and let them set the agenda.
  • Consider referrals to chaplains for follow-up, but ask consent first.
  • Respect any cultural or religious boundaries.
  • Adhere to dress codee and be bare-below-the-elbow.
  • Wear badge at all times.
  • Do make referrals to chaplains for request for prayers/blessings/sacraments etc.
  • Do remember that people may prefer to see a priest/minister or other faith leader, rather than a lay person.
  • Stay in touch with the chaplains. Let us know of any issues.

_items.title: Don't
_items.body:
• Enter wards where the "Stop" sign is displayed at the entrance.
  • Go into rooms or to bedsides displaying "source isolation" signs.
  • Go behind drawn bedside curtains.
  • Assist with feeding, drinking or moving patients.
  • Go onto wards during protected mealtimes.
  • Reveal patient information outside of the hospital.
  • Come into work when you are unwell.

title: Component title
body: Some of our volunteers give a few words about their own chaplaincy work.

title: Component title
body: Reverend Mark Burleigh welcomes you to the team and gives a few words about chaplaincy volunteering.

title: Component title
body: Some members of the chaplaincy team introduce themselves and welcome you to the team.

title: Question 1
instruction: Chaplaincy is an opportunity to impose or spread our own beliefs or views?

_items.feedback: Chaplaincy support should be patient centered and not about imposing our own views on others.

_feedback.correct: Chaplaincy support should be patient centered and not about imposing our own views on others.

title: Question 2
instruction: It is helpful to remember what patients are telling us.

_items.feedback: We should always be listening to what the patient is saying and not saying, rather than thinking about other things (our shopping, our own lives etc).

_feedback.correct: We should always be listening to what the patient is saying and not saying, rather than thinking about other things (our shopping, our own lives etc).

title: Question 3
instruction: Active listening is about talking more than the patient?

_items.feedback: Listening to the patient is the most important part of chaplaincy work. If we are speaking then we are not listening.

_feedback.correct: Listening to the patient is the most important part of chaplaincy work. If we are speaking then we are not listening.

_items.feedback: Care should be patient centered. Not all patients want to be cheered up. However it is also true that being listened to can have a positive influence on a patient's mood.

_feedback.correct: Care should be patient centered. Not all patients want to be cheered up. However it is also true that being listened to can have a positive influence on a patient's mood.

title: Question 5
instruction: It is okay to meet up with patients after they have been discharged?

_items.feedback: Be mindful of boundaries. You should avoid meeting up with patients outside of the hospital setting.

_feedback.correct: Be mindful of boundaries. You should avoid meeting up with patients outside of the hospital setting.

title: End of Training
body:
You have now finished our online chaplaincy training. Please pass on any comments/suggestions or questions about materials you have to your mentor or other chaplaincy team members. You will have a local induction with your mentor who will introduce you to the site you are volunteering at.

From the whole chaplaincy team, we would like to welcome you and thank you for the service that you are going to undertake.

title: Component title
body:
Please work through the pages in the numbered order given. When you reach the end of a page move to the top and use the grey back button to return to the main index of pages. Be aware that there are small crosses on some of the feedback items which when pressed will return you to the page you are on.

Lastly, be aware that some of the audio items will need headphones or speakers. We are hoping that volunteers work through this training at home, and refresh themselves on the content during their probationary period.

The video to the left shows some of the elements used in the training and how to use them.
